revision.text:
{{other ships|HNLMS Jacob van Heemskerck}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=[[File:Jacob van Heemskerck (1906) a.jpg|300px]] |Ship caption=''Jacob van Heemskerck'' }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship country=Netherlands |Ship flag={{shipboxflag|Netherlands}} |Ship name=''Jacob van Heemskerck'' |Ship namesake= |Ship ordered= |Ship builder=''Rijkswerf'', Amsterdam |Ship laid down=1905 |Ship launched=22 September 1906 |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned=22 April 1908 |Ship decommissioned=13 September 1974 |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship honours= |Ship fate= |Ship motto= |Ship nickname= |Ship captured= |Ship status= |Ship notes= |Ship badge= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class= |Ship type=Unique [[coastal defence ship]] |Ship displacement=4,920  tons |Ship length= {{convert|98|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|15.19|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} |Ship draught={{convert|5.69|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} |Ship power={{convert|6400|hp|abbr=on}} |Ship propulsion=2 shafts, [[reciprocating engine]]s |Ship speed={{convert|16.5|kn|km/h}} |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship boats= |Ship capacity= |Ship troops= |Ship complement=340 |Ship crew= |Ship time to activate= |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament=*2 × {{convert|9.4|in|cm|abbr=on}} (2 × 1) *6 × {{convert|15|cm|in|abbr=on}} (6 × 1) *6 × {{convert|7.5|cm|in|abbr=on}} (6 × 1) *4 × 1pdr (4 × 1) *2 × {{convert|45|cm|in|abbr=on}} torpedo tubes |Ship armour=*{{convert|6|in|cm|abbr=on}} belt *{{convert|8|in|cm|abbr=on}} barbette *{{convert|8|in|cm|abbr=on}} turret |Ship notes= }} |} '''HNLMS ''Jacob van Heemskerck''''' ({{lang-nl|Hr.Ms. Jacob van Heemskerck}}) was a unique ''pantserschip'' ([[coastal defence ship]]) of the [[Royal Netherlands Navy]] built by the ''[[Rijkswerf (Amsterdam)|Rijkswerf]]'' in Amsterdam. She was among the ships send to patrol the Venezuelan coast during the ''[[Dutch–Venezuela War|second Castro crisis]]''. After her active career she was rebuilt into a stationary battery ship and recommissioned. During [[World War II]] she was captured by the invading German forces and converted in an anti-aircraft battery. After the war the ship was recovered and given back to the Netherlands, to be converted to an accommodation ship.
==Design== The ship was {{convert|98|m|ftin|0}} long, had a beam of {{convert|15.19|m|ftin|0}}, a draught of {{convert|5.69|m|ftin|0}}, and had a displacement of 4,920 ton. The ship was equipped with 2 shaft [[reciprocating engine]]s, which were rated at {{convert|6400|ihp|abbr=on}} and produced a top speed of {{convert|16.5|kn|km/h}}. The ship had a belt armour of {{convert|6|in|cm|abbr=on}}, {{convert|8|in|cm|abbr=on}} barbette armour and turret armour. Two {{convert|9.4|in|cm|abbr=on}} single turret guns provided the ship's main armament, and these were augmented by six single {{convert|15|cm|in|abbr=on}} guns and six {{convert|7.5|cm|in|abbr=on}} single guns. The ship had a complement of 340 men.<ref name=" navalhistory ">{{cite web |url= http://navalhistory.flixco.info/H/284373x53056/8330/a0.htm| title=navalhistory|accessdate=2012-12-06}}</ref>
==Service history== The ship was built at the ''Rijkswerf'' in Amsterdam. [[Duke Henry of Mecklenburg-Schwerin|Prince Henry of the Netherlands]] attended the launch ceremony and christened the ship on 22 September 1906. The ship was commissioned on 22 April 1908. The same year she, together with the [[Holland class cruiser]]s [[HNLMS Friesland (1896)|Friesland]] and [[HNLMS Gelderland|Gelderland]] were sent to patrol the [[Venezuela]]n coast during the ''[[Cipriano Castro|second Castro crisis]]''.<ref name="Maritieme kalender 1908">{{cite web |url=http://www.hetscheepvaartmuseum.nl/knowledgebase/calendar%7C1908| title=Maritieme kalender 1908|accessdate=2012-11-29}}</ref>
On 16 May 1910 the ship left the port of [[IJmuiden]] to steam for [[Sheerness]] to bring ''Prince Henry of the Netherlands'' to the funeral of [[Edward VII]] of the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland]] that was held on 20 May. During the last part of the journey the ship was escorted by five British [[torpedo boat]]s. Later that year the Belgian king [[Albert I of Belgium|Albert I]] and his wife made a [[state visit]] to the Netherlands. During this visit, they visited the [[IJ (Amsterdam)|IJ]] in Amsterdam where ''Jacob van Heemskerck'', ''Friesland'', {{HNLMS|Piet Hein|1894|2}}, {{HNLMS|Evertsen|1894|2}}, {{HNLMS|O 1||2}} and other Dutch warships were present and fired shots in salute. The pair were given a tour on the ''van Heemskerck''.<ref name="Maritieme kalender 1910">{{cite web |url=http://www.hetscheepvaartmuseum.nl/knowledgebase/calendar%7C1910| title=Maritieme kalender 1910|accessdate=2012-11-29}}</ref>
On 24 July the ship left the port Den Helder for the coronation fleet review of King [[George V]] at [[Spithead]] on 27 June.<ref name="Maritieme kalender 1911">{{cite web |url=http://www.hetscheepvaartmuseum.nl/knowledgebase/calendar%7C1911| title=Maritieme kalender 1911|accessdate=2012-11-29}}</ref>
On 17 May 1917 the ship, together with the [[lugger]] ''Zorg en Vlijt'' picked up the crew of the luggers ''Mercurius'' and ''Jacoba'' that were boarded and later scuttled by a German submarine 50 [[nautical mile]]s off the coast of [[IJmuiden]].<ref name="Maritieme kalender 1917">{{cite web |url=http://www.hetscheepvaartmuseum.nl/knowledgebase/calendar%7C1917| title=Maritieme kalender 1917|accessdate=2012-12-06}}</ref>
===World War II=== After her active career she was rebuilt into a stationary battery ship and renamed ''Batterijschip IJmuiden'' and recommissioned on 19 April 1939. She was stationed in [[IJmuiden]]. During the German invasion in [[World War II]] on 14 May 1940 she was scuttled by her crew to prevent her being captured by the German forces.
The Germans however raised the ship on 16 July 1940 and towed her to Amsterdam on 24 July. From there she was towed to Kiel in March 1941. There she was rebuilt into a floating anti-aircraft battery at the Howaldtswerke and renamed '''''Undine'''''. After the war she was found back in Wilhelmshafen and returned to the Netherlands.
At the ''Rijkswerf'' in Amsterdam she was rebuilt into an accommodation ship. She was recommissioned on 23 February 1948 and renamed '''''Neptunus'''''. This role she fulfilled until her decommissioning on 13 September 1974. On 4 October that same year she was stricken.<ref name="netherlandsnavy.nl">{{cite web |url=http://www.netherlandsnavy.nl/JVH.htm| title=netherlandsnavy.nl|accessdate=2012-10-29}}</ref>
